   Amylase / Lipase:44/38, Differential-Neuts:65.5 %, Lymph:25.7 %,

   Mg++:2.3 mg/dL, PO4:1.9 mg/dL
   [**9-19**] CT Head (Preliminary read):
   Hypoattenuating region in the left frontal lobe, and bifrontal subdural
   fluid
   collections are unchanged from one day prior on non-contrast study.
   [**9-19**] RUQ U/S: Nodular heterogenous liver is non-specific, but may be
   secondary to underlying liver disease. No evidence of cholecysitis.
   Small volume ascites
   [**9-19**] Transthoracic Echo: The left atrium is normal in size. Left
   ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global systolic
   function are normal (LVEF >55%). Right ventricular chamber size and
   free wall motion are normal. There is focal thickening of the right
   coronary cusp of the aortic valve which measures 0.5 x 0.5 cm; cannot
   exclude valvular vegetation. There is no aortic valve stenosis. No
   aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are
   structurally normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. No mass or
   vegetation is seen on the mitral valve. No mitral regurgitation is
   seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There
   is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion.
   IMPRESSION: Focal thickening of the right coronary cusp of the aortic
   valve without aortic regurgitation. Cannot exclude aortic valve
   vegetation. If clinically indicated, a TEE would better assess for
   endocarditis. Preserved regional and global biventricular systolic
   function.
   Culture data: (new results) Serum Toxoplasma IgM and IgG both negative.
   [**9-17**] Stool culture negative for campylobacter, shigella, salmonella.
   [**9-19**] Blood cultures NGTD x2, Sputum gram stain >25 PMNs, 4+ GNR, 2+
   budding yeast. [**Doctor First Name **] (+) 1:160. Aspergillous antigen negative. Toxo PCR
   CSF negative.
   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have listeria brain
   abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status. Given last ABG from [**9-18**], can go down
   on Fi02 (currently at 40%).
   - Will continue current ventilator settings, as she is doing well on 8
   of PS and 5 of PEEP. Ideally would like to wait to see if mental status
   improves before considering extubation.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her. Will follow up iron levels as a high level may pre-dispose to
   listeria infection per ID's note. At this time, left frontal mass
   suspected to be listeria abscess, (per chart notes) neurosurgery feels
   that given positive culture data, should treat this medically without
   surgical intervention.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 3. Will
   need to check gent level 30 minutes prior to 4th dose (tomorrow).
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will follow up final CT abdomen results
no evidence of abscess noted
   on preliminary read however.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - Formal TTE request placed to evaluate for endocarditis (will continue
   to monitor PR interval) as source of bacteremia.
   - Phenytoin for seizure prophylasis, ativan in event of seizure; will
   hold phenytoin given elevated corrected level (today corrected level is
   26.3)
   - Currently checking daily head CT (yesterday, today), then every other
   day for 2 days, then will re-assess.
   - EEG to check for seizure activity given lack of responsiveness.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - Follow up iron studies, DIC panel from this morning, repeat retic
   count.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - Appreciate hematology input.
   - Follow up pending serologies as noted above.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Will consider trial of holding SQ Heparin to see if PTT improves
   (overall coags are within baseline since admission)
   - Continuing to follow head CT
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Patient with elevated LFTs, will continue to monitor
   trend. Will follow up CT abdomen final read, and if LFTs further
   elevated, will check RUQ ultrasound to better evaluate gall bladder and
   CBD.
   -          RUQ as noted above.
   -          Cont to try to obtain outside records
   #) Hypernatremia: Was only getting 30 mL q6H, increased to 150 mL. Will
   recheck in PM.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:

   Multi Lumen - [**2124-9-15**] 01:38 PM

   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease who presented with a seizure and was found to have Listeria brain abscess. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 40%. The ventilator settings are being continued, and consideration is being given to reducing the FiO2 and potentially extubating the patient once her mental status improves.
* Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess: The patient has a positive culture for Listeria in her blood and CSF, and is being treated with ampicillin and gentamicin. A formal TTE is being requested to evaluate for endocarditis as a potential source of bacteremia.
* Pancytopenia: The patient has a pancytopenia, which is being treated with transfusions as necessary. The etiology of the pancytopenia is unclear, but is being investigated further.
* Elevated INR: The patient has an elevated INR, which is being monitored. The possibility of DIC is being considered, and the patient is being treated with FFP and vitamin K as necessary.
* Elevated LFTs: The patient has elevated LFTs, which are being monitored. The possibility of gallbladder or CBD disease is being considered, and further evaluation is being planned.
* Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which is being treated with increased fluid administration.

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

* Sepsis: The patient's Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess make her at risk for developing sepsis.
* Endocarditis: The patient's positive TTE findings suggest the possibility of endocarditis, which could lead to further complications if left untreated.
* Pancytopenia: The patient's pancytopenia could lead to further complications if not properly treated, such as bleeding or infection.
* DIC: The patient's elevated INR and pancytopenia make her at risk for developing DIC, which could lead to further complications if left untreated.
* Gallbladder or CBD disease: The patient's elevated LFTs and possible gallbladder or CBD disease could lead to further complications if left untreated.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 65-inch tall, 57.3 kg male who is currently in the ICU with a diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), bacterial meningitis, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, and hemolytic anemia.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 102.5°F (39.2°C)
* Heart rate: 90 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 121/55 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 30 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 3.7 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 7.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 74 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 22 mEq/L
* Electrolyte levels: normal
* Liver function tests: normal
* Amylase and lipase levels: normal
* Troponin-T level: <0.01 ng/mL

The patient's ultrasound and echocardiogram results show:

* Focal thickening of the right coronary cusp of the aortic valve without regurgitation, which cannot be excluded as a vegetation
* Nodular heterogenous liver on RUQ ultrasound
* No source of septic emboli on CT scan

The patient's medical history is significant for:

* No known drug allergies
* Recent antibiotic use, including vancomycin, metronidazole, cefipime, acyclovir, gentamicin, and ampicillin
* Recent infusion of furosemide, famotidine, and heparin sodium

The patient's current medications include:

* Kepra 500 mg every 3 days, then 1000 mg every 2 days, then discontinue Dilantin
* Furosemide (Lasix) 40 mg every 8 hours
* Famotidine (Pepcid) 20 mg every 12 hours
* Heparin sodium (Prophylaxis) 5000 units every 12 hours

The patient's plan includes:

* Start Kepra 500 mg every 3 days, then 1000 mg every 2 days, then discontinue Dilantin
* Continue furosemide (Lasix) 40 mg every 8 hours
* Continue famotidine (Pepcid) 20 mg every 12 hours
* Continue heparin sodium (Prophylaxis) 5000 units every 12 hours
* Daily head CT scans
* Review of systems and physical examination
* Serial laboratory tests, including complete blood count, electrolyte levels, and liver function tests

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Central nervous system (CNS) complications, such as meningitis or cerebral edema
* Cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or heart failure
* Renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease
* Hepatic complications, such as liver failure or hepatitis
* Coagulopathy, such as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
* Sepsis, including severe sepsis and septic shock
* Anemia, including hemolytic anemia
* Thrombocytopenia, including platelet dysfunction
* Electrolyte imbalances, including hyperkalemia or hypokalemia
* Metabolic acidosis or alkalosis
* Respiratory failure, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

   [**9-19**] CT Head (Preliminary read):
   Hypoattenuating region in the left frontal lobe, and bifrontal subdural
   fluid
   collections are unchanged from one day prior on non-contrast study.
   [**9-19**] RUQ U/S: Nodular heterogenous liver is non-specific, but may be
   secondary to underlying liver disease. No evidence of cholecysitis.
   Small volume ascites
   [**9-19**] Transthoracic Echo: The left atrium is normal in size. Left
   ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global systolic
   function are normal (LVEF >55%). Right ventricular chamber size and
   free wall motion are normal. There is focal thickening of the right
   coronary cusp of the aortic valve which measures 0.5 x 0.5 cm; cannot
   exclude valvular vegetation. There is no aortic valve stenosis. No
   aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are
   structurally normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. No mass or
   vegetation is seen on the mitral valve. No mitral regurgitation is
   seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There
   is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion.
   IMPRESSION: Focal thickening of the right coronary cusp of the aortic
   valve without aortic regurgitation. Cannot exclude aortic valve
   vegetation. If clinically indicated, a TEE would better assess for
   endocarditis. Preserved regional and global biventricular systolic
   function.
   Culture data: (new results) Serum Toxoplasma IgM and IgG both negative.
   [**9-17**] Stool culture negative for campylobacter, shigella, salmonella.
   [**9-19**] Blood cultures NGTD x2, Sputum gram stain >25 PMNs, 4+ GNR, 2+
   budding yeast. [**Doctor First Name **] (+) 1:160. Aspergillous antigen negative. Toxo PCR
   CSF negative.
   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have listeria brain
   abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status. Given last ABG from [**9-18**], can go down
   on Fi02 (currently at 40%).
   - Will continue current ventilator settings, as she is doing well on 8
   of PS and 5 of PEEP. Ideally would like to wait to see if mental status
   improves before considering extubation.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her. Will follow up iron levels as a high level may pre-dispose to
   listeria infection per ID's note. At this time, left frontal mass
   suspected to be listeria abscess, (per chart notes) neurosurgery feels
   that given positive culture data, should treat this medically without
   surgical intervention.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 3. Will
   need to check gent level 30 minutes prior to 4th dose (tomorrow).
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will follow up final CT abdomen results
no evidence of abscess noted
   on preliminary read however.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - Formal TTE request placed to evaluate for endocarditis (will continue
   to monitor PR interval) as source of bacteremia.
   - Phenytoin for seizure prophylasis, ativan in event of seizure; will
   hold phenytoin given elevated corrected level (today corrected level is
   26.3)
   - Currently checking daily head CT (yesterday, today), then every other
   day for 2 days, then will re-assess.
   - EEG to check for seizure activity given lack of responsiveness.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - Follow up iron studies, DIC panel from this morning, repeat retic
   count.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - Appreciate hematology input.
   - Follow up pending serologies as noted above.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Will consider trial of holding SQ Heparin to see if PTT improves
   (overall coags are within baseline since admission)
   - Continuing to follow head CT
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Patient with elevated LFTs, will continue to monitor
   trend. Will follow up CT abdomen final read, and if LFTs further
   elevated, will check RUQ ultrasound to better evaluate gall bladder and
   CBD.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease who presented with a seizure and was found to have Listeria brain abscess. The patient is currently intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 102.5°F (39.2°C)
* Heart rate: 90 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 121/55 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 30 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* CVP: 7 mmHg

The patient has undergone several diagnostic tests, including:

* Ultrasound of the right upper quadrant (RUQ) which showed nodular heterogenous liver and no cholecystitis
* Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) which showed focal thickening of the right coronary cusp of the aortic valve without aortic regurgitation, but cannot exclude aortic valve vegetation
* CT head which showed hypoattenuating region in the left frontal lobe and bifrontal subdural fluid collections
* Blood cultures which grew Listeria
* CSF culture which also grew Listeria

The patient is currently receiving treatment for Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess, including antibiotics and antifungal medication. She is also receiving anticonvulsant medication for seizure prophylaxis.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and may require further respiratory support.
* Sepsis: The patient has a high fever and may be at risk for sepsis.
* Endocarditis: The patient has focal thickening of the right coronary cusp of the aortic valve and may be at risk for endocarditis.
* Pancytopenia: The patient has pancytopenia and may be at risk for bleeding or infection.
* Elevated INR: The patient has an elevated INR and may be at risk for bleeding or thrombosis.
* Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia and may be at risk for dehydration or seizures.

The patient's current medications include:

* Ampicillin
* Gentamicin
* Phenytoin
* Ativan
* Furosemide
* Famotidine
* Heparin
* Insulin
* Tylenol
* Chlorhexidine
* Bisacodyl

The patient's current laboratory results include:

* WBC: 3.7 K/uL
* Hct: 26.0%
* Plt: 74 K/uL
* Cr: 0.6 mg/dL
* TCO2: 24 mmHg
* Glucose: 198 mg/dL
* INR: 1.7
* PTT: 46.2 seconds
* LDH: 373 IU/L
* Ca++: 7.5 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.3 mg/dL
* PO4: 1.9 mg/dL

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Continue current antibiotics and antifungal medication
* Monitor for signs of sepsis or endocarditis
* Continue anticonvulsant medication for seizure prophylaxis
* Monitor for signs of pancytopenia or bleeding
* Monitor for signs of elevated INR or thrombosis
* Continue to follow up with laboratory results and adjust treatment as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease who presented with a seizure, listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely listeria brain abscess. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation for airway protection. Her mental status and c-collar in place limit the ability to extubate her. She has a focal thickening of the right coronary cusp of the aortic valve without aortic regurgitation, which cannot exclude aortic valve vegetation. She has pancytopenia, elevated INR, and elevated LFTs, which are being monitored and treated accordingly. She also has hypernatremia, which is being addressed with increased free water repletion.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate further due to her CNS process, and she may require a tracheostomy or continued mechanical ventilation.
2. Listeria infection: The patient's listeria infection may progress or lead to complications such as abscess formation, meningitis, or sepsis.
3. Pancytopenia: The patient's pancytopenia may worsen, leading to bleeding or infection.
4. Elevated INR: The patient's elevated INR may lead to bleeding or hemorrhage.
5. Elevated LFTs: The patient's elevated LFTs may indicate liver damage or failure, which could lead to coagulopathy, bleeding, or jaundice.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, or seizures.
7. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and presence of lines and tubes may increase her risk of infection.
8. Cardiac complications: The patient's focal thickening of the right coronary cusp of the aortic valve may lead to cardiac complications such as valve dysfunction or endocarditis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider a tracheostomy or continued mechanical ventilation as needed.
2. Continue to treat the patient's listeria infection with antibiotics and monitor for signs of progression or complications.
3. Monitor the patient's pancytopenia and consider transfusions if necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's INR and consider anticoagulation therapy if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's LFTs and consider liver function tests if necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's hypernatremia and consider adjusting fluid management as needed.
7. Monitor the patient for signs of infection and consider antibiotic therapy if necessary.
8. Consider consulting with a cardiologist to evaluate the patient's cardiac status and potential cardiac complications.

   60-year-old woman with disseminated Listeria monocytogenes infection,
   with identified sites including brain abscess, meningitis, bacteremia,
   and possible subdural empyema.  Although the brain lesion has not been
   biopsied, I agree with consultants that the pre-test probability for
   Listeria abscess is so high that risks outweigh benefitis at present.
   Similarly, subdural empyema is possible.
   Listeria monocytogenes infection
   Appreciate help from multiple consulting services.  We will continue
   systemic antibiotics with ampicillin and gentamicin, and follow gent
   levels.  I believe that the best balance of risks and benefits is
   continued antibiotics with watchful waiting for now; both the abscess
   and the subdural collection may well resolve without surgical
   intervention.  Case discussed with ID.

s help.  This is most likely to be related to her

   Will try to get outside records to help sort out the diagnostic data
   supporting autoimmune hepatitis, especially since Listeria sometimes
   presents with hepatitis.

   This is essentially due to neurologic status.  Will evaluate clinically
   as our team gets to know Ms. [**Known lastname 949**].  If appropriate from a

   early tracheostomy since I suspect that any neurologic recovery will be

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current health status as follows:

* The patient is a 60-year-old woman with disseminated Listeria monocytogenes infection, with identified sites including brain abscess, meningitis, bacteremia, and possible subdural empyema.
* She is critically ill, with respiratory failure due to neurologic status, and is on mechanical ventilation.
* She has ongoing fevers, which are likely related to her Listeria infection.
* She has a compromised immune system, with anemia, hyperglycemia, and a possible autoimmune hepatitis.
* She has a C-collar in place, and will require further evaluation by trauma or spine surgery prior to removal.
* She has multiple lines and tubes in place, including an arterial line, multi-lumen line, and a nasogastric tube.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Worsening respiratory failure, potentially requiring more aggressive respiratory support or tracheostomy.
* Sepsis or septic shock due to ongoing Listeria infection.
* Neurological deterioration, potentially leading to permanent brain damage or death.
* Hemorrhage or bleeding due to compromised coagulation function.
* Infection or complications related to the multiple lines and tubes in place.
* Poor wound healing or delayed recovery due to compromised immune function.
* Potential for further organ dysfunction or failure, such as cardiac or renal failure.

Based on the patient's current condition and the potential complications that can arise, it is essential to continue aggressive management of her Listeria infection, respiratory failure, and other underlying medical conditions. Close monitoring and frequent reassessment of her condition will be necessary to prevent and manage potential complications.

   biopsied, I agree with consultants that the pre-test probability for
   Listeria abscess is so high that risks outweigh benefitis at present.
   Similarly, subdural empyema is possible.
   Listeria monocytogenes infection
   Appreciate help from multiple consulting services.  We will continue
   systemic antibiotics with ampicillin and gentamicin, and follow gent
   levels.  I believe that the best balance of risks and benefits is
   continued antibiotics with watchful waiting for now; both the abscess
   and the subdural collection may well resolve without surgical
   intervention.  Case discussed with ID.
   Ongoing fevers
   Appreciate ID
s help.  This is most likely to be related to her
   Listeria.  RUQ ultrasound reassuring.  TTE was abnormal but not
   diagnostic for valvular vegetation; will consult TEE service today.
   Coma
   Appreciate neurology
s help.  EEG adequately excludes non-convulsive
   status.  We will ask neurology to help with prognostic information for
   the family.
   Hepatitis
   Will try to get outside records to help sort out the diagnostic data
   supporting autoimmune hepatitis, especially since Listeria sometimes
   presents with hepatitis.
   Respiratory failure
   This is essentially due to neurologic status.  Will evaluate clinically
   as our team gets to know Ms. [**Known lastname 949**].  If appropriate from a
   prognostic and patient-wishes standpoint, would consider comparatively
   early tracheostomy since I suspect that any neurologic recovery will be
   a matter of weeks to months.
   C-collar
   Review prior imaging.  [**Month (only) 11**] need MRI and spine surgery eval prior to
   removal.
   Anemia
   Follow for now; transfuse for Hct <21
   Hyperglycemia
   Assess after tube feeds resumed
   Communication
   Meeting again today at ~12:15
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale

   Patient is critically ill<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old woman with disseminated Listeria monocytogenes infection, including brain abscess, meningitis, bacteremia, and possible subdural empyema. She is currently in the ICU with respiratory failure, encephalopathy, and listeriosis.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 3.7 K/uL
* Hct: 21.2%
* Plt: 77 K/uL
* Cr: 0.6 mg/dL
* TCO2: 22 mEq/L
* Glucose: 195 mg/dL
* Other labs: Elevated ALT and AST, normal CK and CKMB, elevated LDH, and normal albumin.

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Echo with thickened aortic valve cusp
* RUQ ultrasound reassuring
* TTE was abnormal but not diagnostic for valvular vegetation

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Well-nourished general appearance
* Normocephalic head, ears, nose, and throat
* Soft, non-tender abdomen
* Normal peripheral vascular examination
* Respiratory examination shows clear breath sounds
* Neurologic examination shows the patient is unresponsive with no spontaneous movement and normal tone

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continued systemic antibiotics with ampicillin and gentamicin
* Watchful waiting for the abscess and subdural collection
* Consideration of tracheostomy if appropriate
* Follow-up with neurology for prognostic information
* Review of prior imaging for spine surgery evaluation prior to removal of C-collar

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Further progression of listeriosis, including meningitis and sepsis
* Development of subdural empyema
* Respiratory failure and need for tracheostomy
* Neurologic deterioration and potential need for long-term care
* Hepatitis and potential need for liver transplantation
* Anemia and potential need for blood transfusions
* Hyperglycemia and potential need for insulin therapy

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as needed to prevent these potential complications and ensure the best possible outcome.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely listeria brain abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status. Currently, her mental status and
   c-collar in place limit the ability to extubate her. Her elevated
   respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS process.
   - Will consider trial of extubation versus proceeding straight to
   tracheostomy.
   - Will continue to think forward regarding her respiratory status, as
   it may take considerable time for neurologic recovery to occur. Options
   include possible trial of extubation if c-collar can be removed, or
   proceeding to a tracheostomy. Will consider breathing trial tomorrow.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her, and an iron overloaded state would alsopre-dispose to listeria
   infection per ID's note. At this time, left frontal mass suspected to
   be listeria abscess, (per chart notes) neurosurgery feels that given
   positive culture data, should treat this medically without surgical
   intervention.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 4,
   gentimicin dose checked this morning. Will determine proper once daily
   dosing of gentimicin.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input
will discuss further what the
   predicted recovery may be based on limited patient and case report data
   to help guide family and further management.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - TEE requested to evaluate for abscess and vegetation given that TTE
   could not rule out abscess. Appreciate cardiology assistance. Will
   monitor EKGs for evidence of PR prolongation.
   - Phenytoin for seizure prophylasis, ativan in event of seizure; will
   hold phenytoin given elevated corrected level (today corrected level is
   26.3)
   - Currently checking daily head CT (yesterday, today), then every other
   day for 2 days, then will re-assess per neurosurgery. Currently will
   continue to treat medically, but need to consider tapping subdural
   collections at some point if no improvement (concern for subdural
   empyema).
   - EEG was not supportive of convulsive status.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - Follow up iron studies, DIC panel from this morning, repeat retic
   count.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - Appreciate hematology input, will call with questions.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CT
s as well as coag
s every day or two.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Patient with elevated LFTs, will continue to monitor
   trend. Today all down or stable except for alkaline phos. RUQ
   consistent with liver disease, no other concerning pathology (no ductal
   dilation or gall bladder abnormalities noted. Per discussion with team
   this morning, listeria can have similar presentation to viral
   hepatitis.
   -          Called this morning to obtain records: patient was
   hospitalized at [**Doctor Last Name 918**] in [**Location (un) 841**], CA initially for first episode of
   elevated liver function tests, then followed up with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 979**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 980**] at
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] in [**Location (un) 981**], OR, where she had her liver biopsy and MRCP.
   #) Hypernatremia: Persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible
   losses from fevers, etc. She will need more free water repletion, so
   went up from 30 mL q6H, increased to 150 mL. Will recheck in PM to
   ensure it is improving.
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.

   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status. Currently, her mental status and
   c-collar in place limit the ability to extubate her. Her elevated
   respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS process.
   - Will consider trial of extubation versus proceeding straight to
   tracheostomy.
   - Will continue to think forward regarding her respiratory status, as
   it may take considerable time for neurologic recovery to occur. Options
   include possible trial of extubation if c-collar can be removed, or
   proceeding to a tracheostomy. Will consider breathing trial tomorrow.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her, and an iron overloaded state would alsopre-dispose to listeria
   infection per ID's note. At this time, left frontal mass suspected to
   be listeria abscess, (per chart notes) neurosurgery feels that given
   positive culture data, should treat this medically without surgical
   intervention.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 4,
   gentimicin dose checked this morning. Will determine proper once daily
   dosing of gentimicin.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input
will discuss further what the
   predicted recovery may be based on limited patient and case report data
   to help guide family and further management.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - TEE requested to evaluate for abscess and vegetation given that TTE
   could not rule out abscess. Appreciate cardiology assistance. Will
   monitor EKGs for evidence of PR prolongation.
   - Phenytoin for seizure prophylasis, ativan in event of seizure; will
   hold phenytoin given elevated corrected level (today corrected level is
   26.3)
   - Currently checking daily head CT (yesterday, today), then every other
   day for 2 days, then will re-assess per neurosurgery. Currently will
   continue to treat medically, but need to consider tapping subdural
   collections at some point if no improvement (concern for subdural
   empyema).
   - EEG was not supportive of convulsive status.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - Follow up iron studies, DIC panel from this morning, repeat retic
   count.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - Appreciate hematology input, will call with questions.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CT
s as well as coag
s every day or two.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Patient with elevated LFTs, will continue to monitor
   trend. Today all down or stable except for alkaline phos. RUQ
   consistent with liver disease, no other concerning pathology (no ductal
   dilation or gall bladder abnormalities noted. Per discussion with team
   this morning, listeria can have similar presentation to viral
   hepatitis.
   -          Called this morning to obtain records: patient was
   hospitalized at [**Doctor Last Name 918**] in [**Location (un) 841**], CA initially for first episode of
   elevated liver function tests, then followed up with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 979**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 980**] at
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] in [**Location (un) 981**], OR, where she had her liver biopsy and MRCP.
   #) Hypernatremia: Persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible
   losses from fevers, etc. She will need more free water repletion, so
   went up from 30 mL q6H, increased to 150 mL. Will recheck in PM to
   ensure it is improving.
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.

Summary:

The patient is a 65-inch tall, 57.3 kg male admitted to the ICU with a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), bacterial meningitis, severe sepsis, and hemolytic anemia. The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, antivirals, and antifungals, and has undergone several procedures, including a transesophageal echocardiogram and a CT head scan. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 90 bpm, and blood pressure of 120/53 mmHg. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and has a tracheostomy tube in place.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis and septic shock: The patient's severe sepsis and high white blood cell count (WBC) indicate a high risk of sepsis and septic shock.
2. Meningitis: The patient's bacterial meningitis may lead to further complications, such as increased intracranial pressure, seizures, and long-term neurological deficits.
3. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: The patient's SAH may lead to further bleeding, hydrocephalus, or long-term neurological deficits.
4. Hemolytic anemia: The patient's hemolytic anemia may lead to further complications, such as anemia, jaundice, and increased risk of bleeding.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's mechanical ventilation may lead to respiratory failure, and the patient may require prolonged mechanical ventilation.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac enzymes are elevated, indicating potential cardiac damage, and the patient may be at risk for cardiac arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac arrest.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's SAH and meningitis may lead to further neurological complications, such as seizures, increased intracranial pressure, or long-term neurological deficits.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's abdominal pain and diarrhea may indicate gastrointestinal complications, such as inflammatory bowel disease, diverticulitis, or gastrointestinal bleeding.
9. Infection: The patient's elevated WBC and fever suggest a high risk of infection, and the patient may require further antibiotics or antifungals to manage the infection.
10. Coagulopathy: The patient's elevated international normalized ratio (INR) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) suggest a high risk of coagulopathy, and the patient may require further anticoagulation therapy to manage the risk of bleeding.

Overall, the patient's complex medical condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and ensure optimal outcomes.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely listeria brain abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status. Currently, her mental status and
   limits the ability to extubate her. Her elevated respiratory rate is
   likely secondary to her CNS process.
   - Discussed at length risks and benefits of trial of extubation in this
   patient. Her RSBI is encouraging, but her mental status remains very
   poor. Concern would be for complications if she was failed extubation
   and was difficult to re-intubate.
   - Based on the fact that it is expected the patient would likely remain
   intubated for the foreseeable future, and based on discussions of team
   with family, will consult IP for trach and PEG. Appreciate IP
   assistsance.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her, and an iron overloaded state would alsopre-dispose to listeria
   infection per ID's note. Today there is concern for possible worsening
   mental status, as it took more stimuli for withdrawal and she may not
   have been opening her eyes as she was before. Her CT head yesterday was
   without change. Given question of change in mental status, will check
   head CT again today. If there are any changes in her imaging concerning
   for worsening edema or bleeding, will re-consult neurosurgery.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 4,
   gentimicin dose checked this morning. Will determine proper once daily
   dosing of gentimicin.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input
will discuss further what the
   predicted recovery may be based on limited patient and case report data
   to help guide family and further management.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - TEE requested to evaluate for abscess and vegetation given that TTE
   could not rule out abscess. Appreciate cardiology assistance. Will
   monitor EKGs for evidence of PR prolongation.
   - Phenytoin for seizure prophylasis, ativan in event of seizure; will
   hold phenytoin given elevated corrected level (today corrected level is
   26.3)
   - Currently checking daily head CT (yesterday, today), then every other
   day for 2 days, then will re-assess per neurosurgery. Currently will
   continue to treat medically, but need to consider tapping subdural
   collections at some point if no improvement (concern for subdural
   empyema).
   - EEG was not supportive of convulsive status.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - Follow up iron studies, DIC panel from this morning, repeat retic
   count.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - Appreciate hematology input, will call with questions.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CT
s as well as coag
s every day or two.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Patient with elevated LFTs, will continue to monitor
   trend. Today all down or stable except for alkaline phos. RUQ
   consistent with liver disease, no other concerning pathology (no ductal
   dilation or gall bladder abnormalities noted. Per discussion with team
   this morning, listeria can have similar presentation to viral
   hepatitis.
   -          Called this morning to obtain records: patient was
   hospitalized at [**Doctor Last Name 918**] in [**Location (un) 841**], CA initially for first episode of
   elevated liver function tests, then followed up with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 979**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 980**] at
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] in [**Location (un) 981**], OR, where she had her liver biopsy and MRCP.
   #) Hypernatremia: Persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible
   losses from fevers, etc. She will need more free water repletion, so
   went up from 30 mL q6H, increased to 150 mL. Will recheck in PM to
   ensure it is improving.
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease, who presented with a seizure, listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely listeria brain abscess. She is currently intubated for airway protection and is being treated with antibiotics. Her mental status remains poor, and there is concern for possible worsening of her condition.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: She is intubated and has an elevated respiratory rate, which is likely secondary to her CNS process.
2. Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess: She has positive blood and CSF cultures for listeria, and her recent immunosuppressed state may have predisposed her to infection.
3. Pancytopenia: Her elevated MCV with pancytopenia is consistent with Imuran toxicity, and other possibilities include B12 or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy.
4. Elevated INR: Her INR is elevated, and it is suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
5. Elevated LFTs: She has elevated liver function tests, which may be due to listeria infection or liver disease.
6. Hypernatremia: She has persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible losses from fevers, etc.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening of mental status: There is concern for possible worsening of her mental status, which could lead to complications if she is failed extubation and is difficult to re-intubate.
2. Subdural empyema: There is concern for subdural empyema if the patient's mental status does not improve.
3. Seizure prophylaxis: The patient is at risk for seizures, and phenytoin is being used for seizure prophylaxis.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient has an elevated INR, which may lead to bleeding complications.
5. Liver failure: The patient's elevated LFTs may indicate liver failure, which could lead to complications.
6. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's hypernatremia and hyperchloremia may lead to electrolyte imbalances, which could cause cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust her care accordingly.
2. Consider tapping subdural collections if the patient's mental status does not improve.
3. Continue to treat the patient's listeria infection with antibiotics.
4. Monitor the patient's pancytopenia and adjust her transfusion therapy accordingly.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's INR and adjust her anticoagulation therapy accordingly.
6. Monitor the patient's LFTs and adjust her liver function accordingly.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte imbalances and adjust her fluid therapy accordingly.
8. Consider using a stress ulcer prophylaxis to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding.
9. Consider using a DVT prophylaxis to prevent deep vein thrombosis.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and adjust her care accordingly.

   consistent with abcess in the appropriate clinical setting. No other
   intracardiac source of thrombus is identified. Normal biventricular
   function. No signficant valvular dysfunction.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely listeria brain abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status. Currently, her mental status and
   limits the ability to extubate her. Her elevated respiratory rate is
   likely secondary to her CNS process.
   - Discussed at length risks and benefits of trial of extubation in this
   patient. Her RSBI is encouraging, but her mental status remains very
   poor. Concern would be for complications if she was failed extubation
   and was difficult to re-intubate.
   - Based on the fact that it is expected the patient would likely remain
   intubated for the foreseeable future, and based on discussions of team
   with family, will consult IP for trach and PEG. Appreciate IP
   assistsance.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her, and an iron overloaded state would alsopre-dispose to listeria
   infection per ID's note. Today there is concern for possible worsening
   mental status, as it took more stimuli for withdrawal and she may not
   have been opening her eyes as she was before. Her CT head yesterday was
   without change. Given question of change in mental status, will check
   head CT again today. If there are any changes in her imaging concerning
   for worsening edema or bleeding, will re-consult neurosurgery.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 5. Level
   yesterday was <2, which is goal for once daily dosing.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - TEE as noted
no definite vegetation or abscess seen, but
   abnormalities as noted above.
   - Phenytoin for seizure prophylaxis, tomorrow initiating keppra 1000 mg
   [**Hospital1 **] and stopping phenytoin. Combination of two overlapping
   anti-epileptics could be part of reason for decreased mental status.
   Corrected phenytoin level today is 25.
   - Head CT from last two days without change, checking today to ensure
   no further change given question of change in mental status. If
   unchanged, will check on Saturday, and then again on Monday.
   - EEG was not supportive of convulsive status.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Will work on optimizing reversible factors such as hypernatremia,
   adding lactulose in event that there is a degree of hepatic
   encephalopathy.
   - In event patient has decline or new imaging findings, will again
   address any benefits that decompression or drainage of possible
   empyema/abscess may have. Currently had no evidence of mass effect or
   significant edema on scans.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - Follow up iron studies, DIC panel from this morning, repeat retic
   count.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - Appreciate hematology input, will call with questions.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CT
s as well as coag
s every other day.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Per discussion with team this morning, listeria
   can have similar presentation to viral hepatitis.
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).
   #) Hypernatremia: Persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible
   losses from fevers, increased respiratory rate, and other insensible
   losses. She will need more free water repletion, so increased FW
   flushes to 200 mL Q4H, as wish to avoid D5W in event this may worsen
   cerebral edema (no significant edema at present however).
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.
   - Will continue to trend sodium, re-check this evening.
   #) Finger lesion: Per family, lesion has been present for several
   months. Differential includes foreign object, infection, insect bite.
   No fluctuance or fluid expressed.
   - Will request dermatology consult for further evaluation, appreciate
   assistance.
   #) Question of increased pigmentation: Family provided history of
   darkening skin pigement over last months to years. This also was
   reported in her outpatient visits with her gastroenterologist (at that
   time, her T. Bili was 23). Appreciate dermatology input on this matter
   as well. No evidence of adrenal disease (Addison
s, or
   hemachromatosis).
   #) Gram negative rods in sputum: Unclear if this represents true
   infection, but suspect at present this is likely not true pneumonia as
   she does not have a significant amount of sputum, no leukocytosis, and
   overall fever curve has improved. Chest x-ray also remains unimpressive
   for infection. Will have low threshold to initiate treatment, and will
   have respiratory therapy complete a mini-BAL today to collect further
   culture data.
   #) Hypotension: Patient with transient hypotension this morning. This,
   coupled with her hypernatremia, borderline tachycardia, dry mucous
   membranes, all support volume depleted state. Will continue LR boluses
   to keep up urine output >40-50 cc/hour, SBP >90, and HR<100.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Tube feeds, NPO after midnight for trach/PEG

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease who presented with a seizure, listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely listeria brain abscess. She is currently intubated for airway protection and is being treated with antibiotics. Her mental status is poor, and she is not responding to commands. She has a history of autoimmune disease, iron overload, and is currently being treated with immunosuppressive medications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening mental status: The patient's mental status is poor, and there is a concern for further decline. A head CT scan will be repeated to monitor for any changes in her condition.
2. Pancytopenia: The patient has a history of pancytopenia, which is being monitored and treated with transfusions as needed.
3. Elevated INR: The patient's INR is elevated, which may be secondary to nutritional deficiencies. This will be monitored and treated as necessary.
4. Elevated LFTs: The patient's LFTs are elevated, which may be secondary to liver disease. This will be monitored and treated as necessary.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which is likely due to insensible losses from fevers, increased respiratory rate, and other insensible losses. This will be monitored and treated with free water repletion.
6. Finger lesion: The patient has a finger lesion that has been present for several months. This will be evaluated by a dermatologist to determine the cause.
7. Question of increased pigmentation: The patient has a history of darkening skin pigmentation, which will be evaluated by a dermatologist to determine the cause.
8. Gram negative rods in sputum: The patient has gram negative rods in her sputum, which may represent a true infection. This will be monitored and treated as necessary.
9. Hypotension: The patient has hypotension, which may be secondary to volume depletion. This will be treated with fluid boluses as necessary.
10. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated for airway protection, and there is a concern for respiratory failure. This will be monitored and treated as necessary.

Labs and Imaging:

* Blood cultures: Listeria bacteremia
* CSF cultures: Listeria meningitis
* CT head: No significant change in appearance of left frontal lobe hypodensity with mild local mass effect
* KUB: Large amount of stool with no evidence of obstruction
* Transesophageal echocardiogram: No vegetation on the cardiac valves, small amount of fibrous tissue thickening/echolucency in the fibrous structure connecting the non-coronary cusp of the aortic valve, the anterior mitral valve apparatus, and the interatrial septum that could be consistent with abcess in the appropriate clinical setting

Medications:

* Ampicillin
* Gentamicin
* Insulin gtt/sliding scale
* Phenytoin
* Keppra
* Lactulose
* Colace
* Senna
* Heparin SQ TID
* Chlorhexidine
* Famotidine
* Ativan
* Calcium/Potassium
* Bisacodyl
* PPI (will be changed to [**Hospital1 **] PPI)

ICU Care:

* Nutrition: Tube feeds, NPO after midnight for trach/PEG
* Glycemic control: Insulin gtt/sliding scale
* Lines: Arterial line, multi-lumen, and 20-gauge central line
* Prophylaxis: DVT (heparin SQ TID), stress ulcer (PPI), and VAP (head of bed elevated, chlorhexidine)

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease, who presented with seizure, listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely listeria brain abscess. She is currently intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status. Her respiratory rate is elevated, likely secondary to her CNS process.

The patient's mental status remains poor, and there is concern for possible worsening of her condition. Her CT head from yesterday showed no change, and a repeat head CT today will be performed to ensure no further change. If unchanged, she will be checked again on Saturday and Monday.

The patient has pancytopenia, which is suspected to be secondary to Imuran toxicity, and she is being monitored for trend and transfused if her HCT is <21-22 or symptoms.

Her INR is elevated, suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies, and she is receiving vitamin K and FFPs. Her LFTs are elevated, and she is being monitored for trend. Her RUQ is consistent with liver disease, and listeria can have a similar presentation to viral hepatitis.

The patient has hypernatremia, likely due to insensible losses from fevers, etc., and she will need more free water repletion. She will be rechecked in the PM to ensure her hypernatremia is improving.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Worsening of her mental status, which can lead to further respiratory compromise and potential respiratory failure.
2. Development of sepsis or septic shock due to her listeria bacteremia and meningitis.
3. Hemorrhagic complications due to her coagulopathy and pancytopenia.
4. Liver failure or hepatic encephalopathy due to her elevated LFTs and liver disease.
5. Dehydration and electrolyte imbalances due to her hypernatremia and hyperchloremia.
6. Respiratory failure due to her underlying respiratory disease and potential aspiration pneumonia.
7. Cardiac complications due to her listeria bacteremia and potential endocarditis.
8. Neurological complications due to her listeria brain abscess and potential cerebral edema.

These complications will require close monitoring and prompt management to prevent further deterioration of the patient's condition.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely listeria brain abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status. Currently, her mental status and
   c-collar in place limit the ability to extubate her. Her elevated
   respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS process.
   - Will discuss with trauma surgery or spine surgery removal of her
   c-collar. Concern is that if this remains in place, she cannot be
   easily re-intubated should she fail a trial of extubation. CT c-spine
   was negative for any pathology.
   - Will continue to think forward regarding her respiratory status, as
   it may take considerable time for neurologic recovery to occur. Options
   include possible trial of extubation if c-collar can be removed, or
   proceeding to a tracheostomy. Will consider breathing trial tomorrow.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her, and an iron overloaded state would alsopre-dispose to listeria
   infection per ID's note. At this time, left frontal mass suspected to
   be listeria abscess, (per chart notes) neurosurgery feels that given
   positive culture data, should treat this medically without surgical
   intervention.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 4,
   gentimicin dose checked this morning. Will determine proper once daily
   dosing of gentimicin.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input
will discuss further what the
   predicted recovery may be based on limited patient and case report data
   to help guide family and further management.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - TEE requested to evaluate for abscess and vegetation given that TTE
   could not rule out abscess. Appreciate cardiology assistance. Will
   monitor EKGs for evidence of PR prolongation.
   - Phenytoin for seizure prophylasis, ativan in event of seizure; will
   hold phenytoin given elevated corrected level (today corrected level is
   26.3)
   - Currently checking daily head CT (yesterday, today), then every other
   day for 2 days, then will re-assess per neurosurgery. Currently will
   continue to treat medically, but need to consider tapping subdural
   collections at some point if no improvement (concern for subdural
   empyema).
   - EEG was not supportive of convulsive status.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - Follow up iron studies, DIC panel from this morning, repeat retic
   count.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - Appreciate hematology input, will call with questions.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CT
s as well as coag
s every day or two.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Patient with elevated LFTs, will continue to monitor
   trend. Today all down or stable except for alkaline phos. RUQ
   consistent with liver disease, no other concerning pathology (no ductal
   dilation or gall bladder abnormalities noted. Per discussion with team
   this morning, listeria can have similar presentation to viral
   hepatitis.
   -          Called this morning to obtain records: patient was
   hospitalized at [**Doctor Last Name 918**] in [**Location (un) 841**], CA initially for first episode of
   elevated liver function tests, then followed up with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 979**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 980**] at
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] in [**Location (un) 981**], OR, where she had her liver biopsy and MRCP.
   #) Hypernatremia: Suspect due to insensible losses from fevers, etc.
   She will need more free water repletion, so went up from 30 mL q6H,
   increased to 150 mL. Will recheck in PM to ensure it is improving.
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old female with a complex medical history, including autoimmune disease, who presented with seizure, listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely listeria brain abscess. She is currently intubated for airway protection and is being treated with antibiotics, including ampicillin and gentamicin, for her listeria infection.

The patient is experiencing several medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and requires mechanical ventilation due to her altered mental status and c-collar in place.
2. Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess: The patient has a positive blood and CSF culture for listeria, and her neurosurgery team is recommending medical treatment without surgical intervention.
3. Pancytopenia: The patient has a low white blood cell count, platelet count, and hemoglobin level, which is likely due to Imuran toxicity or other factors.
4. Elevated INR: The patient's international normalized ratio is elevated, which may be due to nutritional deficiencies or other factors.
5. Elevated LFTs: The patient's liver function tests are elevated, which may be due to listeria infection or other factors.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient has a high sodium level, which may be due to insensible losses from fevers, etc.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate further, requiring more aggressive respiratory support or tracheostomy.
2. Listeria infection: The patient's listeria infection may progress, leading to more severe complications, such as sepsis, organ failure, or death.
3. Pancytopenia: The patient's pancytopenia may worsen, leading to increased risk of bleeding or infection.
4. Elevated INR: The patient's elevated INR may increase the risk of bleeding or other coagulation disorders.
5. Elevated LFTs: The patient's elevated LFTs may indicate liver damage or failure, which can lead to serious complications.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, or other complications.

To manage these complications, the patient requires close monitoring and treatment by the ICU team, including:

1. Respiratory support: The patient requires continued mechanical ventilation and close monitoring of her respiratory status.
2. Antibiotic therapy: The patient requires continued antibiotic therapy for her listeria infection.
3. Blood transfusions: The patient may require blood transfusions to correct her pancytopenia.
4. Coagulation therapy: The patient may require coagulation therapy to correct her elevated INR.
5. Liver function monitoring: The patient's liver function should be closely monitored to detect any signs of liver damage or failure.
6. Electrolyte management: The patient's electrolyte levels should be closely monitored and managed to prevent dehydration or electrolyte imbalance.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and treatment by the ICU team to manage her complex medical complications and prevent further deterioration.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a prolonged seizure episode and fevers. The patient's condition has been stable with no significant changes in vital signs, laboratory results, or radiology findings. 

The patient's recent events include a mini-balloon (BAL) done by respiratory, which may need to be repeated tomorrow. The patient's fever has been managed with antibiotics, and a B-glucan test was positive. The neurologist met with the family and discussed the patient's prognosis, which is difficult to assess due to the prolonged seizure and fevers.

The patient's laboratory results show a slightly elevated white blood cell count and a normal platelet count. The patient's blood cultures are pending, and the mini-BAL did not show any microorganisms. The patient's chest CT scan showed no changes, and the head CT scan was stable.

The patient's medical history includes a heterozygous state for TPMT, and the patient was started on antibiotics, including gentamicin and ampicillin.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but the patient's condition can deteriorate rapidly, leading to respiratory failure.
3. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiac status is stable, but the patient's condition can lead to cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's prolonged seizure episode and fevers suggest the possibility of neurological complications, such as cerebral edema or stroke.
5. Infection: The patient's positive B-glucan test suggests the possibility of an infection, and the patient's blood cultures are pending.

In conclusion, the patient's condition is stable, but the patient is at risk for various medical complications. Close monitoring and management of the patient's condition are essential to prevent and treat these complications.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.2°F (38.4°C)
* Heart rate: 91 bpm
* Blood pressure: 113/59 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 23 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 3.7 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 5.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 77 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 21 mEq/L
* Serum glucose: 195 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.6 mmol/L

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Head CT: stable
* Chest CT: stable

The patient's physical examination is significant for:

* Intubation with a tracheostomy tube
* Small cracks in the lips, no bleeding
* Moist mucous membranes
* Regular heart rhythm
* Slightly distended abdomen
* 1+ pitting edema to the ankles
* Mild ecchymosis over the right knee and thigh
* Small amount of withdrawal to noxious stimuli in the left foot

The patient's medical history is significant for:

* Subarachnoid hemorrhage
* Meningitis, bacterial
* Sepsis, severe
* Anemia, hemolytic

The patient's allergies are:

* No known drug allergies

The patient's medications are:

* Gentamicin
* Ampicillin
* Famotidine (Pepcid)
* Heparin sodium (prophylaxis)

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Septic shock
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Hemorrhagic shock
* Neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke
* Infection, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or hematuria

The patient's condition is considered unstable, and close monitoring is necessary to prevent complications and optimize treatment.

   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have lLsteria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status. Currently, her mental status and
   limits the ability to extubate her. Her elevated respiratory rate is
   likely secondary to her CNS process.
   - Discussed at length risks and benefits of trial of extubation in this
   patient. Her RSBI is encouraging, but her mental status remains very
   poor. Concern would be for complications if she failed extubation and
   was difficult to re-intubate.
   - Based on the fact that it is expected the patient would likely remain
   intubated for the foreseeable future, and based on discussions of team
   with family, trach and PEG. Appreciate IP assistsance.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her. There is concern for possible worsening mental status, as now does
   not appear to withdraw to noxious stimuli. Her CT head has been
   stable.  If there are any changes in her imaging concerning for
   worsening edema or bleeding, will re-consult neurosurgery.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 6. Level
   Gent yesterday was <2, which is goal for once daily dosing.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - TEE as noted
no definite vegetation or abscess seen, but
   abnormalities as noted above.
   - Initiated keppra 1000 mg [**Hospital1 **] and stopping phenytoin. Combination of
   two overlapping anti-epileptics could be part of reason for decreased
   mental status.
   - Head CT from last two days without change, checking today to ensure
   no further change given question of change in mental status. If
   unchanged, will check on Saturday, and then again on Monday.
   - EEG was not supportive of convulsive status.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Will work on optimizing reversible factors such as hypernatremia,
   adding lactulose in event that there is a degree of hepatic
   encephalopathy.
   - In event patient has decline or new imaging findings, will again
   address any benefits that decompression or drainage of possible
   empyema/abscess may have. Currently had no evidence of mass effect or
   significant edema on scans.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - This AM FDP 10-40, hapto <20, could be hemolyzing for unclear reasons
   (no literature for Keppra as cause of hemolysis); sending Coombs test,
   will d/w Heme today
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   - Transfusing 2 units for Hct 17, check post-transfusion Hct
   - Repeat hemolysis labs
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CT
s as well as coag
s every other day.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Per discussion with team this morning, listeria
   can have similar presentation to viral hepatitis.  Lipase elevated
   today
           -      recheck lipase
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).
   -          Records from [**Location (un) 841**] pending (faxed request x 2)
   #) Hypernatremia: Persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible
   losses from fevers, increased respiratory rate, and other insensible
   losses. She will need more free water repletion, so increased FW
   flushes to 150 mL Q3H, as wish to avoid D5W in event this may worsen
   cerebral edema (no significant edema at present however).
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.
   - Will continue to trend sodium, re-check this evening.
   #) Finger lesion: Derm evaluated, foreign body with granuloma.
   #) Question of increased pigmentation: Family provided history of
   darkening skin pigment over last months to years. This also was
   reported in her outpatient visits with her gastroenterologist (at that
   time, her T. Bili was 23). Appreciate dermatology input on this matter
   as well. No evidence of adrenal disease (Addison
s, or
   hemachromatosis).
   #) Gram negative rods in sputum: Unclear if this represents true
   infection, but suspect at present this is likely not true pneumonia as
   she does not have a significant/new amount of sputum, no leukocytosis,
   and overall fever curve has improved. Chest x-ray also remains
   unimpressive for infection. Will have low threshold to initiate
   treatment, respiratory therapy completed a mini-BAL yesterday that
   showed no microorganisms or PMNs.
   - Consider formal BAL today with trach
   # Positive beta-glucan.  [**Month (only) 11**] be indicator of fungal infection,
   particularly given recent immunosuppression.
   - ID recs: difficult to interpret in context of abx, recommend
   rechecking, if positive could empirically tx
   #) Hypotension: Patient with transient hypotension overnight. This,
   coupled with her hypernatremia, borderline tachycardia, dry mucous
   membranes, all support volume depleted state. Monitoring closely for
   worsening sepsis. Will continue LR boluses to keep up urine output
   >40-50 cc/hour, SBP >90, and HR<100.

   Tube feeds, NPO after midnight for trach/PEG this AM
